swf so uh what are the different use cases in which you can use Amazon swf
can use swf to dispatch tasks to application components and when you want to coordinate application processing
that's distributed across several components s swf helps you implement ordered execution of application steps
and this ordering can be as simple as a plain sequence of steps or it can be

State s swf helps you manage the application State during distributed execution and for use cases where you

use let's talk a little bit about some of the reasons why we built Amazon swf
as we looked at how applications are being built we found that almost all applications even the simplest ones
require some coordination and State Management and when we looked at different kinds of applications from
simple uh business processes to very complex Auto processing systems and distributed applications we found that
almost all the applications have some kind of workflow in them we also found that orchestration was a fundamental

orchestration capability developers also lack programming models that help them think

Tas we wanted to provide a scalable reliable service in the cloud so that developers can focus on building their

swf we also looked at some of the emerging needs that developers have uh in
building applications we found that more and more developers were using a synchronous interactions and a Loosely coupled

with existing Solutions we also found that developers want to go beyond elastic scaling that

wanted to go beyond that and scale in an efficient manner and they need features such as selective scalability in their
applications so what does Amazon swf give Developers for building Cloud
applications using S swf developers can build applications with components that run anywhere that is they can be
distributed across data centers or multiple clouds uh the components can um
run at any time they can keep running continuously or they might come up at some point in time like a batch Crossing
system and perform the procing and then go away and even intermittently such as
mobile devices we want to encourage developers to think
about tasks in their applications and not about low constructs such as messages we would like developers to
focus on their application logic and save them the development effort that comes from having to build a
coordination platform to run their applications on using S swf developers
can take their applications to Market faster because they have a already made coordination infrastructure on which
they can run their applications and they can scale gradually and pay only for what they use
as we'll see later in the pricing for Amazon swf it's based on a pay as youo
model so there are no high upfront costs developers can also structure
their applications as multiple components that are interacting through Amazon swf and what this gives them is
the ability to scale these components selectively so that when they have a high amount of load for their
applications they don't have to scale the application as the whole but can identify specific bottlenecks and scale
one them and of course using Amazon swf
means there is fewer infrastructure and fewer Administration costs this is because developers no longer have to run

encoded the next step is to actually encode the video and then the encoded video needs to be protected with
DRM and finally the encoded protected video is saved in a location that's
accessible to the user so in building Amazon s swf we
encourage developers to think about the various components of their application that perform actual work like in this
case the workers that perform encoding and the workers that perform our DRM
audition but also to think about their application flow logic and encapsulate that within a decider so all of these

code a piece of code or component that kicks off workflow executions in this case we are assuming
that there is a web server frontend that accepts the video URL from a user and it
starts the execution with that URL and also as you can see from the
picture here some the workers are running on the cloud whereas others are running behind firewalls and talking
towf over simple HTTP
calls so the deer and the workers talk to S swf through a special form of
polling called long polling long polling removes some of the complexity in figuring out the frequency
of polling and balancing that with the latency needs of your application the way long ping works is
that when a worker or a decider performs a poll request Amazon
swf will hold on to that poll request for up to 1 minute or until a task is
available to be handed to that worker and Amazon s swf also creates
task list based on type names provided by the worker and the decider you can
think of task list more like cues but they are managed by S swf and the
placement of task within those task list is coordinated by S
swf so to walk through the an execution the web server fend makes an API call to
Amazon s swf to start a workflow execution of a particular type in this case it's a video transcoding
application workflow for each workflow execution Amazon s swf creates a record which it
maintains in a consistent manner throughout the execution and even after the execution completes everything that happens in
that execution is recorded in this history record so to start with when the workflow execution starts the input data
provided is recorded is recorded in the execution history whenever the execution history
changes Amazon has WF sends a task to the
decider the decider now looks at the history and it can drive the application
logic so at this point the deci looks at the history and it figur that uh the
execution is just started and a video URL is available to be encoded so as per
the logic of this application the next step is to encode the video the decider returns a Deion to
schedule the encoding of the video back to Amazon swf s swf adds this as a task
to the encode T encode task list and this task is then handed to the worker that performed encoding
when the worker is done with the encoding task it Returns the results back to Amazon s
swf in this case it can perform the encoding place the encoded video or say
in an S3 bucket and provide the URL of the S3 bucket back as a result to Amazon
swf s swf records that the encode task is complete together with the results of
that of that task now there might be cases where uh task might time out or
task might fail that is a worker has picked up a task but couldn't execute the task and return a result specifying
that the execution failed in all these cases Amazon swf will notify the decider
that something has happened to a task that has been that was previously scheduled the decider can make decisions
such as retrying a task or it might decide to give up and just complete the workflow execution with a failure code
when the decider looks at the execution history it sees that the encode task is now complete and as for the application
Logic the next task is to add DRM protection so it Returns the de to
Amazon s asking s swf to schedule a task for DRM Deion S swf adds that to the DRM task
list and also records that a new task has been added to the task list in the execution
history it then hands the task over to the worker that performs DRM and this worker might take a while
to perform this DRM task but what this means is that during this time other executions can be running and the
decider and the worker for encoding can be processing those
executions when the worker for adding DRM completes that the result of that
task are recorded in the book for execution history and then the decider is again notified that the execution history has changed
the decider now looks at the execution history and figures that the encod task
is complete and the DRM task is complete and there is nothing else to do as per the application logic so it completes
the workflow which is also recorded in the execution history and as I mentioned before Amazon
s swf maintains a separate history record for each of the executions and it
can scale to a huge number of executions wherein several executions are running in parallel and the task for all of them
are managed and tracked by Amazon
ssws so a little more detail into what Amazon swf provides the most important
thing or two of the most important things that Amazon provide is reliable non-duplicated delivery of task and
consistent State Management across distributed components so one of the fundamental
problems that we've seen developers have with queuing systems is that sometimes they might get duplicates and there are
very few guarantees about how tasks are delivered s swf guarantees that the same task will not be handed to two different
workers and also tracks what happens to the task once it's been scheduled and
once it's been picked up by a worker there is built-in queing in
Amazon S swf and S swf also gives you control over how tasks are routed to
workers you can set many different kinds of timeouts such as a timeout for for
the time that a task has been scheduled to when it's been picked up by a worker also time out for the entire execution
of a workflow and all these time outs are tracked by Amazon swf as a mentioned before s swf
consistently maintains the state of the system so that you don't have to what this means is that the execution State
need not be recorded by your decider or by your workers and that if effectively
makes them stateless and what this also means is that you can scale them and and also uh replace them when
you need to S swf tracks each of these executions on the task independently and it makes
them available the status of those tasks and also metrics about those tasks and workflow executions avable both through
visibility apis and through the management consoles for long learning executions
Amazon provides durability in State Storage so if an execution is running
for about a year and tasks are not happening on a continuous basis s swf
keeps the state of each task that has happened so that when the next task is SCH needs to be scheduled maybe six
months from the previous task we can always go back to Amazon aswf to look up the state of that particular execution
and make decisions based on that so here's a general flow of how you
would build an application using Amazon swf this isn't a trick flow there are many of these uh functions that you
would perform maybe in a different order but in general when you look at an existing application or a new
application that you're going to be building you would you would want to separate out the application flow logic
from the actual activities that need to be performed by your application you then set up certain
constructs in Amazon s like domains and you also register workflow and activity
types domains are a very simple mechanism to group some of these constructs that you register with s
swf when you Define workflow types and activity types there are certain configuration parameters such as default
timeout that you can provide when you register them but the key thing to keep in mind is that you're not telling s swf
the flow of your application when you register a workflow type an activity type you are free to use use them you're
free to use activity types in different workflows the entire logic of your application is encapsulated into the
code that you write for your decider and not through any definition that you provide to Amazon
SW then you have to build your workers and deciders and the workflow initiation
code as we previously saw since you since you manage the
workers and the deciders you have complete freedom in how you deploy them and how many of workers and deciders you

Workforce that are that are run um in a particular time period um how many of

the workflow history which paen was mentioning primarily contains all the

closed yes this is B there are a couple of questions about um you know basic questions about writing deciders and
activi code so the question was Will users have to write both decider and activity code uh yes when using S swf we
want to give users complete control over both the execution of the activities and
also the uh application flow logic so developers will write both the deci and
activity code however it's very easy to wrap existing code that you might have and even existing Legacy systems that
you might have um by simply writing an adapter that talks the S swf API or uses
the flow framework and on the back back side talks to your legacy system or
existing code uh there's also a question about why the logic is separated in the decider so one good reason for you to um
think about the application flow logic um separate from your activities is that
you might want to plug out uh different activities and replace the implementations that you have for them
whereas in general the application flow logic which might involve some conditional logic that also uses some
Dynamic runtime stage all of this can be encapsulated into the decider code and it also gives you the strength to use
several uh programming languages so your workers can be implemented uh in say
Ruby or uh python whereas your decided code might be implemented in Java or it
might be implemented in a different modeling framework which is adapted to use
aswf there's also a question about um pricing in terms of what are the chargeable actions so U setting
scheduling tasks setting timers um setting markers and sending signals
these are all counted as chargeable actions and um they are all charged at the rate of 25 cents for um 10,000s of
them and there is also a free tier allowance for them um this question
about charges for long running processes so if your execution completes within 24
hours there are no ongoing execution charges so in that case you pay for starting the workflow execution and also
for the various chargeable actions that you perform during the workflow execution uh if your workflow runs for
longer than a day then in addition to those charges you pay for uh every day that it that the workflow execution runs
and and the benefit you get from s swf is that you're able to query the state
of the application at any time and if you choose to retain it the same benefits are available to you even after
the workflow execution completes
